title: birmingham laziest in britain
story: People from Birmingham take the fewest steps each day — and 70 per cent have no intention of getting fit.The average Brummie manages just 3,769 daily steps, way off the recommended 10,000.Fittest city is Norwich where they do 10,073 — the only place to hit the target.They are also most likely to call themselves “fitness fanatics” and hit the gym three times a week or jog at least twice.Londoners came second with 8,408 steps in a survey of 2,000 adults.Overall, 63 per cent admitted making excuses to dodge the gym and 54 per cent said they would rather watch TV.The second laziest city was Glasgow, followed by Belfast and Edinburgh.The fittest behind Norwich and London were Leeds and Oxford.Pollster DW Fitness First gyms said: “It’s easy to think of excuses not to exercise but in the long run you’ll always feel better for it.”GOT a story? title: dup slam barnier irish border plan
story: The EU’s chief negotiator wants British officials to police goods travelling between Belfast and the rest of the UK to “de-dramatise” internal UK checks.Eurocrats are trying to calm fears their backstop proposal will create an Irish Sea border by using technological solutions pinched from Brexiteers.But Unionists said they will continue to reject any plan that keeps just Northern Ireland in the Customs Union and parts of the Single Market.Their opposition to the new proposal effectively kills it stone dead because Theresa May wouldn’t be able to get in through parliament.The DUP’s sole representative in Brussels, Diane Dodds, questioned whether the new plan “represents a serious departure from the EU’s dogmatic stance”.She told The Sun: “The DUP remains firmly opposed to the core tenet of the original plan published by Michel Barnier, which would see Northern Ireland remain tied to EU rules and cut adrt from the rest of the United Kingdom post-Brexit.“We will not countenance anything which affects the constitutional position of Northern Ireland within the Union, creates barriers to and within the UK internal market or erects barriers in customs or regulation.”Under the EU’s new plan, which is being cooked up to “de-dramatise” the backstop, Max Fac style technology would be deployed in the Irish Sea.Mr Barnier has said it would be easier to carry out checks on ferries than at the land border, where both sides have committed to no new infrastructure.Brussels recently asked for internal UK trade data that it hoped would strengthen its case.However, the figures show 45% of all goods travelling between Great Britain and the island of Ireland go through Belfast.They also reveal that far less trade between the two islands is done by big businesses than Brussels had hoped, limiting the effectiveness of technology.Mrs Dodds said: “Suggestions that the EU is now considering technology-based solutions are a positive  belated development.“However this will become null and void  based only on the EU goal of ensuring Northern Ireland remains in a common regulatory and customs areas inside the EU.“Equally we are unconvinced by political and economic arguments which suggest that a technological border in the Irish Sea is more deliverable than on the land border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.”A senior EU diplomat insisted: “One way or the other there have to be checks, so let’s make them as seamless as possible.”Top Brussels figures also insisted last night that the PM must water down her Chequers plan further before they’ll change their own negotiating position.Sources said there was no suggestion yet that EU leaders are prepared to loosen the instructions they gave to Mr Barnier at a key October summit.Member States have also hardened their resolve on how detailed the political declaration on trade should be after Michael Gove suggested the UK could ditch Chequers after Brexit.A senior diplomat said: “There’s still a lot of movement necessary from the UK side before we can actually reach agreement, and that has mostly to do with the political framework for the future relationship.”And a top French official insisted the declaration on trade cannot leave any “ambiguity” that can be exploited by the UK, adding: “The  is not important, we think its main point is that it must be clear.”A UK Government spokesman said: “We are clear that any backstop proposal would have to preserve the constitutional and economic integrity of the UK.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pregnancy weight unhealthy kids
story: Piling on excess pounds by “eating for two” raises the risk of a child being fat by the age of seven, researchers claim.High blood pressure and poor blood sugar control — a symptom of diabetes — are also dangers for the youngster.But mums-to-be who do not put on enough weight can have kids with the same blood pressure and sugar issues, plus stunted growth.Researchers from the Chinese University of Hong Kong studied 905 women and their kids.They said it proves a need to monitor maternal nutrition and physical activity.But the Royal College of Midwives said some of its members are not even provided with scales.The RCM’s Mandy Forrester said: “There is a clear need for midwives to have the tools, guidance and training they need so they can offer women the best possible support and care.”GOT a story? title: philip hammond brexit gaffes sun says opinion
story: His boss, the Prime Minister, insists we will thrive whether there’s a Brexit deal or not. The EU has to know that she is unafraid to walk away  need be.What does her blundering Remainer Chancellor do?Volunteers his own apocalyptic warning about No Deal reversing our progress since the 2008 crash.Mr Hammond has leapt on the IMF’s latest doom-laden predictions and swallowed them whole, despite its abysmal forecasting record over the financial crisis, austerity and the Brexit vote.The Chancellor has already hampered vital No Deal preparations, undermined the new Brexit Secretary and only last week suggested delaying our departure.Now, at a stroke, he has sabotaged our negotiating hand and boosted the EU’s.It is a measure of the weakness of Mrs May’s position after the loss of her majority that Mr Hammond is still in his job.REMEMBER Brussels mocking the Brexiteers’ idea of high-tech customs checks to solve the Irish border problem?The technology didn’t exist, they said. It was a “fantasy island unicorn model”.Triumphant Remoaners piled in. It proved Brexiteers were clueless, they chirped. And Downing Street then ­produced its convoluted alternative.Except the EU, in the form of Michel Barnier, now believes in the fantasy island unicorn model too. The trouble being it wants it used between Britain and Northern Ireland instead of Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.And the DUP, whom Theresa May needs for her survival, won’t wear that. Nor should they, since it ides the UK.Funny though, isn’t it, how Brussels move the goalposts when it suits them? They have negotiated in bad faith all along.TOO many politicians are in denial about the soaring cost of the NHS and social care. So we applaud Health Secretary Matt Hancock’s imaginative plan to sort the latter.The new lelong insurance system he is considering, compulsory for all workers unless they take a risk and opt out, looks a practical idea to fund part or all of an OAP’s care costs.It would give them peace of mind that they wouldn’t have to spend their savings or the proceeds from their home.Maybe it will work. Maybe not. Regardless, it is to Mr Hancock’s credit that he is starting a grown-up conversation at last over future funding of health.For too long progress has been stymied by the Left using any change to the NHS as a political weapon.But the structure of a health service designed in 1948 now needs a radical rethink.It is time reality dawned.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: newlywed couple photobombed bear
story: Allison Baumli, 27, and her groom Tabor Baumli, 28, got permission for ten minutes of snaps at Minnesota Zoo after their ceremony.Photographers Kristy Clarke and Chris Mueller shot comedy gold when the beast called Kenai stuck his nose in — looking rather sad.We quickly posed the couple and the bear took one look at the bride and his jaw literally dropped.It honestly looked like he was amazed at her beauty.His eyes then turned to the groom and he seemed to look displeased.It was then that we prompted the couple to kiss and the bear had the saddest look on his face.He left us with photos that we will remember forever.He is one funny bear!GOT a story? title: kim jong un south korean president moon jae third summit north korea
story: Hundreds of people waving unication flags watched on as the two leaders greeted each other as friends at Pyongyang airport.They walked with Moons we Kim Jung-sook, and Kims we Ri Sol-ju, past a military honour guard, then drove into the city where security had been ramped up.Hundreds of North Koreans wearing suits and traditional dresses also greeted Moon, carrying flowers and waving Korean peninsula and North Korean flags.A sign behind them read: We ardently welcome President Moon Jae-ins visit to Pyongyang!The two leaders stepped out of the same black Mercedes vehicle with open-top rear seats to arrive at Paekhwawon State Guest House, where Moon will stay.The guesthouse was also used by two former South Korean presidents during their own summits with Kims father, Kim Jong Il, in 2000 and 2007.Kim and Moon will hold formal talks from 3.30pm to 5pm , Moons office said.Moon is hoping to use the meeting to improve relations between the Koreas and reboot stalled nuclearisation talks between the North and the US.Travelling with Moon are business tycoons including Samsung scion Lee Jae-yong, underscoring Moons hopes to expand cross-border business projects.Currently, all major joint projects between the Koreas are stalled because of US-led sanctions.Moon was expected to have talks with Kim on Tuesday and Wednesday and  to Seoul on Thursday, according to his chief of staff.The pair were also expected to jointly announce the results of their talks on Wednesday  things go smoothly.North Koreas state-run media reported the two will reaffirm their previous commitments to peace, prosperity and the reunication of the Korean Peninsula.This is Moons first trip to the North Korean capital, though he has met Kim twice at the border village of Panmunjom.He is under intense pressure from Washington to advance the denuclearisation process.Before his departure he said he intends to push for irreversible, permanent peace and for better dialogue between Pyongyang and Washington.Speaking just before his departure, Moon said: This summit would be very meaningful  it yielded a resumption of North Korea-US talks.Its very important for South and North Korea to meet frequently, and we are turning to a phase where we can meet anytime we want.The North just completed an elaborate celebration complete with a military parade and huge rallies across the country to mark North Koreas 70th anniversary.Talks between the US and North Korea, which Moon brokered through his April and May summits, have stalled since Kims June meeting with President Donald Trump in Singapore.North Korea has taken some steps, like dismantling its nuclear and rocket-engine testing sites.But US officials have said it must take more serious disarmament steps before receiving outside concessions.Although Trump has indicated he may be open to holding another summit to resuscitate the talks.

title: storm ali uk weather helene
story: The Met Office has issued a danger to le warning with gusts predicted to cause chaos across the UK.News of Ali comes after Storm Helenes strong gusts knocked out power for communities, with 193 homes in Cornwall forced to call in engineers early this morning.Forecasters have cancelled the yellow severe weather warning in place for Helene today - but worse conditions are expected tomorrow.Met Office meteorologist Rachael West said:  “Storm Ali is expected to move across UK during Wednesday with Northern England, Scotland and Northern Ireland experiencing some heavy rain.“But the greatest impact of the storm will be the strong winds which is why we have issued a yellow warning – with an amber later this morning for parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland.“We could see winds of up to 85mph for the areas within that amber warning when we expect the storm to hit tomorrow morning.“It’s going to be a very windy start to the day.”“Weather like this is quite typical for this time of year because we do see areas of low pressure that become active and bring strong winds.”While the weather warning for today has been downgraded, Britons have been informed that damage to buildings, power cuts, road closures and transport cancellations are still possible.Meteorologist Dean Hall said parts of the UK felt gusts of about 30-40mph this morning, with wind speeds reaching 50mph in parts of Wales.But Storm Helene, which was downgraded after initial warnings that it may pose a risk to le, is moving away towards the north east.Weve got rain currently across Scotland, northern England, eastern parts of Northern Ireland, associated with what was Storm Helene, Mr Hall said.Temperatures have remained mild with a fairly warm start to the day as temperatures reached 20C in some parts the country.Unlike yesterdays bright and sunny conditions, showers will move in but these will be swamped by Storm Ali.

title: woolly mammoths new jurassic park style theme park
story: In less than 10 years it is hoped the fearsome big cats will be released from an underground lab as part of a remarkable plan to populate a remote spot in Russia with Ice Age animals cloned from preserved DNA.Experiments are already underway to create the lions and also extinct ancient horses found in Yakutia, Siberia, seen as a prelude to restoring the mammoth.Regional leader Aisen Nikolaev forecast that co-operation between Russian, South Korean and Japanese scientists will see the “miracle”  of woolly mammoths inside ten years.He said: “The prospect was no longer fantastical.Today, technology is developing at an explosive pace, and what yesterday seemed to be scientic nonsense, today is an absolutely clear prospect for scientists.”Mr Nikolaev claimed the remarkable  of the extinct beasts will be possible because of DNA material of the giants found in the permafrost in Yakutia, also called Sakha Republic.He said: We are actively working with South Korea.“Thanks to cooperation with Korean and Japanese scientists, in my opinion, this [cloning a mammoth] will happen in the next decade.In 2014 he first proposed “an Ice Age Park with mammoths” to act as home for them to roam, he said.Further details of the incredible plans for the new “world class paleo-genetic scientic centre” will be unveiled next month when Vladimir Putin hosts a major investment forum.The cloning laboratories - some sunk deep in the permafrost soil - aim to extend research by Russian scientists who are already working closely with South Korean specialists hoping to restore extinct species. Yakutsk is capital of diamond-rich Sakha Republic, also known as Yakutia,  where 80 per cent of finds of samples of Pleistocene and Holocene animals with preserved soft tissues have been made.The scheme of the new centre will be unveiled at the 4th Eastern Economic Forum hosted by Putin opening on 11 September in Vlaostok. It will “aim to study extinct animals from living cells - and to restore such creatures as the woolly mammoth, woolly rhinoceros, cave lion and breeds of long-gone horses”, reported The Siberian Times.The cloning scientists are already using DNA from the ancient animals has been preserved in remains encased in frozen soil - or permafrost - for tens of thousands of years. The centre will be based at Russia’s Northern-Eastern Federal University  which is seeking further investment for the extraordinary project.   Expert Dr Lena Grigorieva - who drafted plans for the centre - said: “There is no such unique material anywhere else in the world.”But scientists would also explore ways of helping fight human diseases, she said. “We study not only Pleistocene animals - another line is the study of the history of settlement of the North-East of Russia,” she said.  Northern ethnic groups have a unique ancient genetic structure. “Such studies will help in the study of rare genetic diseases, their diagnosis, prevention.”The university has existing close cooperation with South Korean SOOAM Biotech Research Foundation, led by cloning expert Professor Hwang Woo-Suk.There are also links between Russian scientists and trailblazing Hard University geneticist Professor George Church who plans to inset woolly mammoth genes into an Asian elephant embryo by 2020.Prof Church has revealed to Sun Online how a cloning project was on the verge of being able to grow a baby mammoth in a lab.His team of leading Hard scientists have been using DNA recovered from a woolly mammoth found perfectly preserved in ice in Siberia after dying 42,000 years ago.By merging genes from the mammals with that of elephants their species may be resurrected.The team are set to publish in the coming weeks scientic papers laying out in detail their revolutionary technique in creating and implanting mammalian embryos.Speaking to exclusively to Sun Online, Prof Church said: “We have already revived dozens of genes and are testing them in elephant cells.“We are focusing on a reviving mammoth genes and making a mammoth/elephant hybrid and help them spread to vast wild, arctic climates.”Using a genetic engineering technique called CRISPR-Cas9 gene-editing, his team of scientists can “cut and paste” strands of DNA into elephant stem cells with a precision not seen before, paving the way for a woolly mammoth embryo. Prof Church said he wants to then grow a hybrid woolly mammoth/elephant hybrid within an articial womb rather than using a female elephant as a surrogate mum. It is estimated this will take at least 22 months.The prof believes this will allow woolly mammoths herds to begin once more plodding about the arctic and while doing so save the world. Along with other measures, its hoped the woolly mammoths will create an environment which could stop Siberias permafrost melting and then releasing billions of tons of greenhouse gases.The doomsday scenario has been dubbed as the “methane bomb” because  it happened it would dramatically worsen climate change, melting the ice cap and flooding countries across the world.And there is clear evidence that this is already happening.Bubble like mounds have been popping up like a geological plague and some have already burst and spewed out toxic gas which damages the atmosphere.But the worst of this ticking time bomb has yet to happen. Much of the methane is still trapped underneath by the permafrost layer which is fast disappearing and threatens to release the gas at any moment. An area where this is starting to happen is the Yamal Peninsula. Shocking aerial footage has revealed thousands of methane-filled craters — which threatens to happen across Russia’s frozen far north.Ironically, melting ice here revealed preserved woolly mammoths that are now being used in the cloning attempts.And  the huge furry mammoths/elephant hybrids were to be brought into being, Prof Church said they could repopulate these freezing wastelands and help lock in the lethal fumes. He said: “Cold-resistant elephants would flatten the insulating snow and supporting trees in winter and favour the highly heat reflective grass in summer.Should Prof Church and his Hard uni team successfully clone woolly mammoths they would be taken to an extraordinary Ice Age safari park currently being developed by Russian scientists.Called the Pleistocene Park, the 20,000 hectare zone in the furthest stretches of remote Siberia has been created in a bid to recreate an Ice-Age ecosystem. Boffins believe grazing woolly mammoths would also compact the snow in the winter and grass in the summer all of which lowers the permafrost temperature.In a previous interview, park director and scientist Nikita Zimov told Sun Online: By the time mammoths will be cloned,  theyre cloned and brought to the park, we will have a system.Theyll eat shrubs, break down shrubs. Theyll trample down the grass, eat the grass. The park is to show animals can transform the vegetation.If the park, which is already populated with bison, horses, moose, reindeer and muskox, is successful it will be expanded across the north in areas where there is a risk of mass methane release.

title: brits take to twitter to share windy memes as storm helene batters uk with 70mph gales
story: Forecasters issued severe weather warnings  – but online wind-up merchants were quick to joke about the conditions.The storm obviously passed some by and they shared photos of single deck chairs and wheelie bins knocked over to poke fun at the predictions.Others who clearly felt the brunt of the gusts tweeted pictures of a businessman holding onto iron railings for dear le and a cat clinging to a tree.But while tweeters made light of Storm Helene, the Met Office said Britain is set for further wind and rain.Storm Ali will bring 85mph gales and an amber weather warning when it hits tomorrow.

title: left wing labour staff in bolshevik plot to keep control of the party if jeremy corbyn suddenly steps down
story: Emergency plans are reportedly being drawn up to severely restrict the powers of his deputy Tom Watson  he becomes “acting leader”.All decisions would therefore have to go through the hard-left National Executive Committee as part of attempts to stop moderates taking back control of the direction of Labour.There are fears that in the months-long period while a leadership contest is arranged and run, opponents of the Corbyn project will seek to roll back the changes he has made.The HuffPost said a proposed rule change drafted by senior allies of the current leader would add a brand new clause to the Labour constitution.It would effectively put the NEC in charge rather than Mr Watson, by setting out the “acting leader’s scope for action, powers, requirement for approval of actions by the NEC and any other qualications on the scope of the role”.The wording of the change, which is buried in the papers being discussed at today’s meeting of the executive and has no guarantee of being passes, has sparked anger among MPs.One told HuffPost: “This looks like they’re trying to turn the NEC into the Politburo with greater power than the acting leader.“But it also looks like someone is trying to lay the ground for the departure of Jeremy at some point over the next year.”And a senior figure added: “It’s an unenforceable act of paranoid Bolshevism.”But Mr Corbyn is currently showing no signs of wanting to step down, and a Labour source said it was “complete and utter rubbish” to suggest he was intending to resign.Mr Watson, who was elected by the member with his own mandate back in 2015, and has repeatedly found himself at odds with his boss.He was involved in the failed 2016 coup against the Labour leader, and despite being more loyal since the 2017 election he has been critical in recent weeks over Mr Corbyn’s handling of the anti-Semitism crisis.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: work bosses have no idea what their staff get up to according to employees
story: A poll of 2,000 working adults found around one in three reckon their managers are totally oblivious about the jobs they do on a daily basis.It also emerged another 41 per cent believe their boss would be unable to complete a day’s work in their job.And more than one third think their boss is grossly overpaid for the work they do – or don’t do.The study was undertaken by Perkbox to coincide with the launch of its new product Insights, an innovative tool to measure and improve employee engagement.Bill Hewitt, product manager for Perkbox Insights, said: “As your company or team grows, keeping on the pulse of your most valuable asset, your people, becomes harder and harder - especially  they’re split across dferent locations or dialling in from all corners of the world.“Perkbox Insights helps create a simple, transparent feedback loop between management and staff so that you can break down these silos and retain a sense of connectedness, no matter how big or messy you think you’re business is getting.”The study found a fth of employees don’t feel their boss is understanding or empathetic, so it’s unsurprising nearly a quarter said their manager isn’t concerned for their well-being and happiness at work.In fact, 17 per cent reckon their supervisor is ‘clueless’ about their feelings, and a fth said their manager has even made negative comments about colleagues.It also emerged employees rarely get the chance to discuss their professional future, despite having four conversations with their direct line manager every day.Employees up and down the country will have an average of just three conversations a year about their career prospects and the direction their role is heading in.And in a typical month, workers will have just two catch ups with their boss regarding their workload.As a result, hard-working professionals find themselves feeling frustrated, annoyed or fed-up with their manager.Three in 10 also admit they get on with their boss but only in a professional environment.And a third feel they don’t get enough recognition for the hard graft they put in.However, an equal number said they work well with their manager, both professionally and personally, with many feeling appreciated and rewarded by their supervisor.In fact, staff reap the rewards, getting some form of recognition once a week, on average and more than half feel they get enough credit where it’s due.More than a third of employees believe their boss works harder than they do, and 68 per cent said they deserve to be in their position.The study, conducted via OnePoll, also found employees don’t need grand gestures to feel valued as 47 per cent would simply like to be told when they’ve done a job well.This is compared to 25 per cent who would like to be appreciated with a complimentary meal on the company, and 35 per cent who would prefer to be awarded ‘Employee of the Month’ for their hard work.However, more than half would enjoy an incentive to motivate their work ethic such as a voucher or gt card to drive their output.And 42 per cent would like to get vouchers or discounts to commend a job well done.Bill Hewitt added: “Perkbox Insights works on the simple premise that, ‘the more questions you ask, the more you’ll be able to discover and improve’.It does all the legwork for you, automatically spotting and highlighting team and company trends.“Give your employees the feedback and visibility they crave and it will help everyone connect the dots and feel empowered to create change.”

title: groom surprises bride on their wedding day with a six foot long giant subway sandwich
story: Fortunately for new husband James Coad, 30, it wasn’t a case of lost delivery drivers, but all part of his cunning plan.The secretive spouse organised the giant Subway sarnie to be delivered in the middle of his wedding speech, as a special reminder of his very first date with his new we, Lucinda, 26.James, of Hemel Hempstead, said: “Lucinda and I have been together for five years now.We met at work, as you do, but we didn’t really hit it off at first – in fact she thought I was a bit of an idiot.“I fancied her a little bit, and one night in 2013 we all went on a typical work night out to welcome some new faces in the office.“Lucinda and I hit it off with a bit of flirting, then we went to our local nightclub, Veeda, and shared a passionate kiss in the R’n’B room.“Later in the night I took her to Subway and thought I’d be romantic by offering her an Italian six-inch BMT.“But when I handed it to her – she dropped the whole lot on the floor. I didn’t offer her mine though, that went home with me.“We always have a laugh about Subway now, and when we walk past we joke about the way we first met.”But it wasn’t until wedding planning was well underway that James had the bright idea to involve the sandwich chain in his big day, making sure nobody else knew about it – not even his best man.He said: “I was writing my speech and thinking of the first time we met, and was stumped because ours wasn’t love at first sight, she didn’t really like me that much.“The Subway story came to mind straight away. I ordered three sandwiches, an Italian BMT, Ranch Chicken and Veggie Delight.But it’s the BMT that links back to that special night in 2013.”Subway sandwich artist Justin Pringle, 42, who made and delivered the Giant Subs from the Jarman Park store in Hemel Hempstead, said, “James told us about the jokes he and Lucinda share after she dropped her BMT sub on the night they first got together.We were delighted to help him surprise Lucinda with some Giant Subs at their wedding – and luckily no one dropped these ones.”Justin and his team created three giant subs for the reception, including one with the BMT filling, which was delivered to James and Lucinda as part of the groom’s speech.The specially baked giant sub, which is designed to feed a group of up to 25, measures a whopping six-foot, and costs from £116.It takes two hours and 30 minutes to make a giant sub, from dough to plate.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family kept neighbours as slaves
story: Victims Kate Dagley, 45, and her daughter Karen Jenkins, 27, were subjected to brutal beatings and given rations of dried pasta and one cigarette a night.Ms Dagley was held prisoner by Jean Kelly, 53, her husband Michael, 43, who lived in the same block of flats in Coventry.Meanwhile Miss Jenkins was kept as a slave at another flat where the Kellys daughter Anastasia Hitt, 25, lived with her partner Ian Healy, 29, and their baby.A court heard the family forced the terried mum and daughter to clean their flats, change nappies and feed the dog.Wheelchair-bound matriarch Jean beat the vulnerable women with a baseball bat she nicknamed Bob and gloried in their suffering.Yesterday Jean Kelly was found guilty of two charges under the Modern Slavery Act after a trial at Warwick crown court.Michael Kelly, Hitt and Healy all admitted assault and falsely imprisoning Ms Dagley.The court heard Jean Kelly falsely accused Miss Jenkins of stealing money.Prosecutor Graham Russell told the trial jury: “That was just a pretext for violence, false imprisonment and forced labour.“The reality was she had to suffer ‘the beats,’ repeated and sustained violence.“During one incident, Mrs Kelly called her husband who started on the daughter with his fists as she hit her with the baseball bat and continued to do so after Michael left.”The Kellys forced Miss Jenkins to live and work at Hitts flat in the Wyken area of Coventry last year, the court heard.She was kept prisoner for three weeks, ordered to sleep on the living room floor, fed only uncooked pasta to eat, and paid one cigarette a night for her work as their skivvy.Mr Russell told the court: “Her free will was comprehensively extinguished. She was serving Anastasia Hitt under coercion.”Giving evidence, Miss Jenkins told the jury: “I don’t remember how many  I had. I was constantly getting booted and punched, booted and punched.“It was mainly Ian, but Michael would join in, and  he stopped, Jean would join in.”Some of the strongest evidence of the women’s ordeals was unwittingly provided by Hitt herself – because she had a phone app that recorded all conversations.In one recording, Hitt discussed Miss Jenkins being “locked in,” and complained about her speaking to a social worker through the letterbox.Describing another conversation, Mr Russell said: “They’re taking a ghoulish delight in the level of abuse their two prisoners can stand.”The victims were finally saved when police received an anonymous tip-off and they raided the two flats.Miss Jenkins had suffered extensive facial injuries, a fractured breastbone and a broken finger.Her mum had two fractures to her back, two broken ribs, and bruises all over her face.Ms Dagley told the court: “They would lock me up every night, and then let me out in the morning to help Jean in her flat, and then lock me up again at night.“It was all of them.”Prosecutors said Jean Kelly was the ringleader who directed the detention and forced labour of both victims.Mr Russell said: “She boasted cruelly in phone calls to her daughter about the injuries inflicted on both women. She appeared to glory in their suffering.The defendants will be sentenced next month.

title: female big game hunter slammed by celebs
story: The unveried image of the woman, only referred to as Britany L, has been shared to US based Safari Club International and has since sparked world-wide outrage.But it turned out it is perhaps no surprise the hunter was posing with the dead animal.For animal experts believe the slaughtered leopard was likely the ninth largest ever hunted. The backlash was first sparked by South African artist Sue Dickinson, who dubbed Britany L a “cretin” in a Facebook post on September 10.Before long this attracted 42000 comments and 217,000 shares.And by Friday, it was shared by anti-ivory poaching group Knot On My Planet founder David Bonnouvrier who asked his followers to find this b****.Celebrities like Naomi Campbell and Dutch supermodel Doutzen Kroes also expressed horror.Ms Kroes wrote: “How can you find pride and pleasure in killing a beautul animal like this large male Leopard.The woman in the picture should be ashamed of herself! I find this disgusting and I’m so upset, sad and angry that this still happens!!While Campbell tweeted: A very large male Leopard recently killed by Britani L. Member of the safari club international based in Tucson AZ call them and give them a piece of your mind.Wealthy hunters, mostly from America, pay up to £60,000 to track and kill a fully grown elephant. Other animals popular with trophy hunters are lions, leopards, rhinos, buffalos and deer.Every hunter must purchase a license that allows them to hunt. A license for an elephant, for example, is more costly than that for a lion.However, some nations completely outlaw the practice. Botswana, for example, argues that it can become an exclusive tourist destination that brings in more cash than it loses from the hunting ban.The outrage comes after numerous female big game hunters have being posting their kills online. In July an American big game hunter caused outrage for slaughtering a rare black giraffe during a South Africa hunting trip.Tess Thompson Talley posted photos of herself posing with the slain creature online about a year ago.Meanwhile another hunter reportedly took her own le after being targeted by animal terroristsLast year hunter Melania Capitan claimed she had been targeted by trolls for years because of her hunting, with vile comments including that she should receive a beating.Former American beauty queen and passionate hunter Olivia Nalos Opre revealed she received over 1000 hate messages in an HOUR when Cecil the lion was shot and once had a bounty of £40,000 on her head.

title: bmw to shut mini factory for a month after brexit day sky sources
story: The development shows one of Europe's most successful and influential companies revealing how disruptive it expects no deal to be, and its lack of faith in a deal being reached.Workers have been told that the annual summer maintenance shutdown will have to be moved to April, as the company is obliged to take action against its fears of a shutdown of the cross-channel supplies required to make its cars.BMW and the rest of the car industry have long warned the government, both privately and in public, of the Brexit threat, and in particular the no deal threat to its "just in time" supply chains. Sky News visited the Oxford factory last year, revealing the shock at government not knowing what the terms of a future relationship with the EU27 would be.The move will cost millions, and will have a knock-on effect for thousands of workers across the BMW supply chain.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"A BMW spokesperson told Sky News: "Planned annual maintenance periods at BMW Group production sites allow essential updating and equipment replacement to be completed over several weeks, while there is no production taking place."As a responsible organisation, we have scheduled next year's annual maintenance period at MINI Plant Oxford to start on 1 April, when the UK exits the EU, to minimise the risk of any possible short-term parts-supply disruption in the event of a no-deal Brexit."While we believe this worst case scenario is an unlikely outcome, we have to plan for it.

title: governments 100000 net migration cap not policy migration advisory committee chair says
story: It also suggested EU citizens be given no preference over those from countries outside the bloc.If implemented, the reforms would be "the biggest change to the UK labour market in a generation", the Resolution Foundation said.Former home secretary Amber Rudd ordered the report last year to analyse the impact of Brexit on immigration after the implementation period, expected to begin on 1 January 2021.It was released on Tuesday, making recommendations to the government and giving one of the most comprehensive pictures yet of migrants in the UK. Prof Manning said he judged one of the Conservatives' central immigration pledges to be a "political target", not an immigration policy.Former prime minister David Cameron made the promise in 2010 that net migration should be under 100,000 a year. It has been repeated by his predecessor Theresa May.The latest ONS figures show this currently stands at 244,000.The report's key findings:: UnemploymentThere is no evidence that EEA migrants have reduced employment opportunities for UK-born workers, on average.Migration raises unemployment among certain groups - the young and less well-educated, according to some evidence. This finding is subject to "signicant uncertainty".:: WagesThere is no evidence that EEA migration has reduced wages for UK born workers, on average.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2":: ProductivityImmigration has, on average, a positive impact on productivity.The impact is larger for high-skilled migrants than low-skilled migrants.:: The NHSEEA migrants make a larger contribution - both in terms of money and work - to the NHS than they receive in health services.There is no evidence that migration has reduced the quality of healthcare.:: House pricesMigration from EEA countries - those in the EU and others including Norway and Iceland - has reduced the cost of "personal services".Migration has also raised house prices, more in areas where house-building is restricted.A Home Office spokesperson said they would "carefully consider" the recommendations.They said: "After we leave the EU, we will take back control of our borders and put in place an immigration system that works in the interests of the whole of the UK.

title: liberal democrat glee club targets sir vince cable and tim farron
story: To the tune of "It's a Sin" by the Pet Shop Boys, delegates chorused: "When I go back upon Newsnight You know it's going to cause you pain I'm speaking on gay sex again."For every single interview No matter when or where or who Has gay sex in common too."It's a, it's a, it's a, it's a sin."Since standing down as Lib Dem leader last year, Mr Farron - a committed Christian - has said he regrets eventually saying he does not believe gay sex was a sin.It followed weeks of him being asked the question in the weeks before the 2017 election. In other new lyrics sung by Lib Dem members on Monday night, Sir Vince's call for the party to become a "movement for moderates" was also mocked.To the tune of military march "Men of Harlech", the gathering sung: "Men and moderates whose inaction Kept in power the Tory faction Drove supporters to distraction Sitting on the fence.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"Ex-MP and former Lib Dem deputy leader Sir Simon Hughes was spotted enjoying the singsong on the last night of the party's conference.The party's Glee Club has been criticised by alcohol charities in previous years for a song featuring lyrics about late leader Charles Kennedy's alcohol addiction.Lib Dem members will gather again on Tuesday to hear Sir Vince's keynote address.

title: macron mania 300k of presidential memorabilia sold in days
story: A blue T-shirt with the word president embroidered on the breast costs a stately &#836455 .Some of Mr Macron's most famous quotes feature in the products, with one T-shirt bearing the caption "Poudre de perlimpinpin" - meaning "fairy dust" which was a remark Mr Macron used during a debate with Marine Le Pen ahead of the election.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"Posters, watches, notebooks, bags and pens are also included in the 60-odd items, with sales being boosted by a pop-up shop at the Elysee Palace over the weekend.The event was billed as part of France's Heritage Days and Mr Macron dropped in to greet visitors.

title: meghan needs to face the media to win over the doubters
story: After numerous visits Meghan, a self-confessed foodie, was the one who decided a cookbook was the best way for them to raise the money they need.It is the clearest message yet of the kind of work that she wants to support empowering women, supporting erse communities and providing a voice for those in need.With her sleeves rolled up, and helping out with the cooking, we are left in no doubt that she wants to be a hands-on royal.This was a signicant moment for those of us who follow the royals on a daily basis, for a while we have wanted to know what Meghan's charitable focus is going to be.But this was delivered to the media in a way I was not expecting - a pre-prepared video filmed privately by the palace. A big announcement like this would usually come with a public appearance and a media event in front of the cameras, maybe a promotional video, but also a chance to see for ourselves what the project is all about.Seeing is believing continues to be an important mantra for the royal family.Interviews were arranged inside the palace, with a representative from the Royal Foundation and women from the community kitchen.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"Most people just want to see the nice pictures and watch the videos, don't they?But it is a trend, not just from the royals but with a growing number of high profile iniduals, happy to stick with social media to promote their brand, and avoid the questions you would face from traditional media.Former editor of The Sun, Dominic Mohan, now runs his own PR agency and said it can be dficult to convince clients to engage with journalists.Talking about the pitfalls of social media content he said: "The material can look very sanitised and it does not really undergo the same journalistic rigour or questioning.""So, I think that there should be a hybrid approach, the palace needs to balance it out with traditional media and social media."However they have had their fingers burned quite badly. The palace, with their handling of Meghan's father, for instance, so maybe this is a bit of a fight back from that." I have been lucky enough to follow the royals around the world their convening power and ability to effect change is extraordinary.

title: ofcom joins calls for independent internet regulation
story: Such time requirements have drawn criticisms from free speech campaigners, who have expressed concerns that social media companies are not equipped to make the decisions about whether content is legally acceptable or not.Last year, YouTube deleted potential evidence of war crimes in Syria following pressure to tackle terrorism propaganda on its platform.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"A cross-party panel discussion in the House of Lords in July agreed on the need for an independent internet regulator, although the panel stressed strengthening existing regulatory capacity rather than creating a new watchdog.The aim should be develop the infrastructure for regulation, Ms Coldicutt said at the time, echoing an independent report by Mark Bunting, a partner at Communications Chambers, which was commissioned by Sky.Mr Bunting's report warned of the risk of "regulation by outrage" and cites communication regulator Ofcom, which stated: "Effective regulation requires a clear definition of the services that are to be regulated, a specic account of the potential harm to be addressed, and hence a clear rationale for the specic regulation."

title: south korea leader moon jae in arrives in pyongyang for summit with kim jong un
story: It is the third time the two leaders have met this year, having previously held talks in the Koreas' shared border village of Panmunjom.Mr Moon said he is pushing for "irreversible, permanent peace" and for better dialogue between Pyongyang and Washington during "heart-to-heart" talks with Mr Kim.Both leaders want the US to sign off on formally ending the Korean War, which still technically continues because no peace treaty has ever been signed. title: labour chiefs draw up plans
story: NewsLabour chiefs draw up plans to prepare for Jeremy Corbyn's 'sudden resignation'The new rules would limit the role of deputy leader Tom Watson  Corbyn unexpectedly quitShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent11:12, 18 SEP 2018Updated13:14, 18 SEP 2018NewsThey're keen to introduce the rule change immediately "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour chiefs have drawn up plans to prepare for Jeremy Corbyn’s ‘sudden resignation’, it has been reported. The proposal would restrict the powers of deputy leader Tom Watson in the event that the Labour leader steps down unexpectedly, according to HuffPost . Under current rules, Watson would become acting leader  Corbyn was incapacitated or quit without warning, until a leadership election can be called. The change would effectively put Labour’s ruling body, the National Executive Committee  in charge of the acting leader, and give them approval over his or her powers.  It says the NEC should have the power to set out the “scope for action, powers, requirement for approval of actions by the NEC and any other qualications on the scope of the role.” And the amendment introduces the new reform “immediately”, without being ratied by this year’s party conference. It includes a ‘sunset clause’ puts it in place pending a more permanent solution being approved at the 2019 party conference. Corbyn has repeatedly insisted he plans to lead Labour into the next election, and there's no indication he is planning to step down. One MP told HuffPost : “This looks like they’re trying to turn the NEC into the Politburo with greater power than the acting leader.  It comes as the NEC is braced for a showdown over rewriting the party rulebook to give members more of a say. The trade unions and Momentum group are set to clash over several planned changes including to how the party selects its leader. But last minute changes by general secretary Jennie Formby mean the group can sidestep the bitter row over mandatory reselections for MPs which has been rumbling within the party for the last few months. Party members and trade unions are set to be handed new powers in the reselection of sitting MPs under a compromise plan aimed at ‘opening up’ contests for Westminster seats but which falls short of mandatory reselections. Reports also suggest unions could be given a stronger role in the leadership election nominations.

title: real lolita tragic girl 11
story: NewsThe real Lolita: Tragic girl, 11, was kidnapped and raped for months - and inspired Nabokov's scandalous novelVladimir Nabokov's novel about a professor who becomes obsessed with his teenage step daughter was inspired by a real le case of child abuse and abduction according to crime author Sarah WeinmanShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySarah Weinman12:30, 18 SEP 2018NewsSally Horner was abducted by a criminal posing as a father of one of her school friends "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne March afternoon in 1948, Sally Horner walked into a five-and-dime store located on one of Camden, New Jersey's busiest downtown streets. She was there on a dare: to steal a five-cent notebook, the initiation rite for joining a girls' club at her elementary school. Sally, just a month shy of her eleventh birthday, was desperate to join that clique. She was lonely, confiding her troubles in her school teacher. Her father had committed suicide when she was six. Her mother, Ella, struggled to find and keep work as a seamstress. Her older sister, Susan, was due to give birth to her first child later that summer, which would make Sally an aunt. Then a hand tugged on her arm.  A middle-aged man, positively ancient to young Sally, announced he was an FBI agent, and that Sally was under arrest. And  she didn't do as he said, she would be packed off to reform school. Sally understood how terrible a fate this would be. The man said he would let her go this time, but he could come back and find her, without any warning. Three months later, in June 1948, that man found Sally again as she walked home from school. He threatened her again, upping the ante: Sally had to tell her mother that he was the father of school friends, promising a week's worth of vacation on the Jersey Shore. Sally went home and told her mother the concocted story. Ella believed it. On June 14, Ella took Sally to the Camden bus station, kissed her goodbye, and saw her go away on a bus, sitting next to a man she'd never seen before. That man wasn't an FBI agent. Sally Horner was never under arrest. And the man, who called himself many names but was generally known as Frank La Salle, a career criminal only months removed from a prison term for the statutory rape of five girls between the ages of 12 and 14.  What was supposed to be a vacation transformed into a cross country nightmare that lasted twenty-one months. It took Sally from Camden to Atlantic City, to Baltimore, to Dallas, and then to San Jose, Calornia, where she was rescued – with the help of a concerned neighbour with secrets of her own – in March 1950. But Sally hardly had a chance to grow up, to recover fully from her rescue. Only two and a half years later, she would die in a tragic car accident at the age of 15. News of that car accident spread far and wide.  Sally's initial rescue was a national media sensation, even covered as far as Australia and New Zealand. But her death reached one vital inidual: the novelist Vladimir Nabokov. He read of it in the New York Times, copied the information down on a notecard  and, from the summer of 1952 through the end of 1953, wrote the rest of the novel that had so vexed him for the previous five years. That novel became Lolita, its account of a middle-aged man's obsessive, illicit, and illegal desire for a twelve-year-old girl still controversial more than sixty years after publication in 1955. And Sally Horner's plight, and its inspiration for Lolita, hid in plain sight, like a neon sign read to flash under the right circumstances, thanks to a parenthetical aside by the novel's unreliable narrator, Humbert Humbert, who wonders: “Had I done to Dolly, perhaps, what Frank Lasalle [sic], a fty-year-old mechanic, did to eleven-year-old Sally Horner in 1948?”  Research Several years ago, I stumbled upon what happened to Sally Horner while looking for my next crime story idea. Sally' s kidnapping, terrying odyssey, and dramatic rescue caught my attention with particular urgency. Here was a young girl, victimised over a twenty-one month odyssey from taking her from Camden, New Jersey to Atlantic City, then on to Baltimore, Dallas, and Calornia, by an opportunistic child molester named Frank La Salle. Here was a girl who figured out a way to survive away from home against her will, who acted in ways that baffled her friends and relatives at the time. Here was a girl who survived her ordeal when so many others, snatched away from their lives, do not. Then for her to die in a car accident just two and a half years after her rescue, her story then subsumed by a novel, one of the most iconic, important works of the 20th century, immortalised by that single parenthetical hardly anyone noticed. No wonder Sally Horner got under my skin in a way that few stories ever have before or since. No wonder I spent months chasing down court documents, talking to family members, visiting some of the places she had lived – and some of the places where her abductor, La Salle, took her. And even after a Canadian online magazine published my article about Sally's le and its connections to Lolita in the fall of 2014, I knew I wasn't finished with Sally. Or, more accurately, she was not finished with me. What drove me then and galls me now is that Sally’s abduction defined her entire short le. She never had a chance to grow up, pursue a career, marry, have children, grow old, be happy. She never got to build on the fierce intelligence so evident to her best friend that, nearly seven decades later, she spoke to me of Sally not as a peer, but as a mentor. After Sally died, her family rarely mentioned her or what had happened. They didn’t speak of her with awe, or pity, or scorn. She was only an absence. For decades Sally’s claim to immortality was as an incidental reference in Lolita, one of the many utterances by the predatory, middle-aged narrator, Humbert Humbert, that allows him to control the narrative, and of course, to control twelve-year-old Dolores Haze. Like Lolita, Sally Horner was no “little deadly demon among the wholesome children.” Both girls, fictional and real, were wholesome children.  Contrary to Humbert Humbert’s assertions, Sally, like Lolita, was no seductress, “unconscious herself of her fantastic power.” The fantastic power both girls possessed was the capacity to haunt. Over the four and a half years I spent working on The Real Lolita, I talked with a great many people about Lolita. For some it was their favourite novel, or one of their favourites. Others had never read the book but ventured an opinion nonetheless. Some loathed it, or the idea of it. No one was neutral. Considering the subject matter, this was not a surprise. Not a single person, when I quoted the passage about Sally Horner, remembered it. I can’t say Nabokov designed Lolita to hide Sally Horner from the reader. But given that the narrative moves so swtly, perhaps an homage to the highways Humbert and Dolores traverse over many thousands of miles in their cross-country odyssey, it’s easy to miss a lot as you go. Even casual readers of Lolita, who number in the tens of millions, plus the many more millions with some awareness of the novel, the two film versions, or its place in the culture these past six decades, should pay attention to the story of Sally Horner. Because it is the story of so many girls and women, not just in America and the UK, but everywhere.

title: how much princess eugenies wedding
story: NewsHow much will Princess Eugenie's wedding cost? Who will pay hefty price tag revealedPrincess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank's wedding has been criticised by some, who claim they should have a smaller and cheaper celebrationShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor09:21, 18 SEP 2018Updated09:47, 18 SEP 2018NewsIt's going to be a very special day "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrincess Eugenie is set to marry her long-term boyfriend Jack Brooksbank next month in an extravagant two-day long wedding. The royal gang will be out in force on October 12 for the celebration, which will be held in the same church as Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding in May. Despite being ninth in line to the throne and carrying out no official royal duties, Eugenie's wedding is actually going to bigger than her cousin's. Not content with just one day of celebrations, the happy couple's guests will enjoy a two-day party including a formal reception and a 'festival and funfair themed' party the following day. But weddings don't come cheap - especially when you're a member of the royal family and your guest list includes some of the most famous faces in the world.  They've also decided to make their wedding plastic-free, which will be costly, and they're planning to take a carriage ride around Windsor to wave to well-wishers which will come with a hefty security bill. Dad Prince Andrew was said to have demanded a glitzy event, similar to Harry and Meghan's, for his younger daughter with Sarah Ferguson. A royal source said: The Duke of York has insisted his daughter's wedding must be a huge occasion to be remembered and wants everyone to get on board to celebrate the happy couple. So how much is all this going to cost? And more importantly, where is the money coming from? How much is the wedding going to cost? Wedding planning company Bridebook has calculated roughly how much the royal wedding is going to cost, including everything from the venue, the food, the dress and the entertainment.  According to their estimations, the total bill will come in at around &pound2,820,620 . This is how they've broken it down: The venue - &pound85,000 to &pound300,000 Eugenie and Jack's ceremony will be held at St George's Chapel in the grounds of Windsor Castle. The Queen will then host an afternoon reception in the castle, before guests head back to Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson's home Royal Lodge. This means they won't have to pay for the venues themselves, however having a wedding at home can be equally pricey.  The experts at Bridebook believe the couple are likely to have a marquee to keep the guests warm on the October evening. They'll also need a fully-equipped catering tent and potentially more for other behind-the-scenes bits. However they could also pick a glass style marquee, which is what Pippa Middleton had for her wedding, which could cost &pound300,000. The dress - &pound230,000 There's a lot of speculation around who Eugenie will pick to create her wedding dress, and all we know so far is that it will be a British designer . She's known for her bold and quirky style, so people are excited to see what she looks like on the day.  Bridesbook believe she will spend about &pound230,000 on the dress. Bridesmaid dresses - &pound5,000 We're yet to receive a full list of Eugenie and Jack's bridal party, but it's likely that Princess Beatrice will be the maid-of-honour. The sisters are incredibly close, so it would be surprising  the princess doesn't have her big sister by her side on her special day. Royal weddings are known for their young bridesmaids and pageboys, so we might get to see Prince George and Princess Charlotte in the role again.  Whoever they pick, the couple will need to splash out for bridesmaids dresses and suits for their nearest and dearest Groom's outfit - &pound6,050 While it's nowhere near as exciting as the bride's dress, we're sure Jack will look very smart for his big day. The wedding invite states the dress code is morning suits, which suggests he will be wearing the same. We doubt he'll be wearing off the rack, so a bespoke tailcoat, waistcoat and trousers normally cost around&pound4,400.  On top of that you've got new shoes, which could be around &pound900, and of course the second outfit for the evening celebrations which could be an extra &pound3,000. Booze - &pound84,500 This is one area we assume Jack has taken the lead on, as he's got a lot of experience with bars and nightclubs. He's the UK Ambassador for George Clooney's tequila company and he used to own his own nightclub. Meghan and Harry had their own cocktails at their wedding - called When Harry met Meghan - so there's a chance Eugenie and Jack might do the same. There's also likely to be a lot of champagne and of course a lot of tequila! Flowers - &pound100,000 Wedding flowers are an important part of the wedding, and by picking an autumn wedding Eugenie will have lots of beautul flowers to choose from.  Bridebook believes the cost of the bouquets and decorating the church and reception venues will cost around &pound100,000. Photographer and wedding video - &pound17,000 Even though they will have the world's media photographing all the public parts of their special day, Eugenie and Jack will probably also have their own snapper there. If they want a A-list photographer, like Meghan and Harry, they'll have to splash out a lot of cash. There's also a chance they'll have a wedding video to capture all those special moments. Cake - &pound5,600 As anyone who has planned a wedding before will know, the second you put the word 'wedding' in front of cake you automatically have to add a few zeros.  Stationary - &pound30,000 We're yet to officially see the wedding invitations, but pictures of them have been leaked online. Entertainment - &pound25,000 to &pound55,000 This is probably going to be a large chunk of their wedding cost, and it's likely that there will be lots of performers and other fun things for the guests to enjoy. Toilets - &pound16,000 This isn't something many brides have to think about when planning their big day, but as the second part of their celebration will be outdoors they might have to sort out some extra loos. We suspect they'll opt for something a bit fancier than festival-style portaloos for their big day, but pretty much whatever they pick will come with a cost. According to the experts, this could cost them an extra &pound16,000.  Who will be paying? The wedding parties will be paid for by the Queen and Princess Eugenie's parents Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson. However the hefty security bill, including the costs to keep them safe during the open-top carriage procession, will be picked up by the taxpayer. The news caused outrage with people up and down the country , with many claiming we should not be contributing to a big party for a non-working member of the royal family, especially when they've got the cash to fund it themselves. Emma Dent Coad, Labour MP for Kensington – where Eugenie and Jack live in Kensington Palace at a vastly reduced rent – slammed their plans.

title: katie hopkins end inevitable just
story: NewsopinionKatie Hopkins' end was inevitable - she was just a story, not a journalistShe paid the price in the end, says Fleet Street FoxShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist14:40, 17 SEP 2018Updated00:30, 18 SEP 2018Newsopinion"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI have long felt sorry for Katie Hopkins. She is a woman not only out of her depth, has not only floundered for more than a decade, but has no idea where she's gone wrong. It's hard to see her without thinking of a fly batting itself against a window until it expires, able to see the fresh air but unable to find it. If she reads this - which she might, because she defines herself only by what others think of her - she'll assume I'm a Left-wing liberal about to rail against her Right-wing freedom of speech. No, Katie. Someone who knows more than you is going to explain how the hatred has suffocated you. We both have epilepsy - mine very mild, hers very severe. The condition strikes in her sleep, led to her being expelled from Sandhurst, to break vertebrae and frequently dislocate her shoulders. She recently had brain surgery that ended the seizures but left her with a hole in her skull and needing to re-learn how to climb stairs. She blames the medication she has needed since young for the fact her oldest daughter is autistic and her youngest was born with a deformed hip that required many surgeries to correct. Those would be enough disability for most people to deal with. But Katie has an extra one - a mistaken belief that she's a journalist.  Let's not be precious about the Street of Shame. It is a trade, not a profession, and the only qualication necessary is a level of enthusiasm bordering on mental illness. But somewhere along the line most journalists get training. They get it from a practical degree, a vocational course, or at worst from paying attention to people who're doing it already. Katie became a journalist because first she became a media star, and she managed THAT with what she called being outspoken and everyone else called being a right cow. On The Apprentice in 2006 she hogged the camera by making amusingly-nasty remarks about maternity leave, fat people, and fellow contestants. She resigned at the end of the penultimate show citing childcare concerns, which others mocked because she had known what she was getting into. But it's perhaps worth noting both that her concerns were for two disabled daughters, and also that she was mocked mainly because she'd been so happy to mock others.  Katie sold her story for six-figure sums, had celebrity spats, and was pictured in flagrante in a field with someone else's husband. She got a regular column in her local paper the Exeter Express &amp Echo , but it ended after an online poll found 84% of the readers wanted her fired. It was a hint she did not take. She was invited onto TV as a guarantee of ratings. Three years ago Buzzfeed reported a former staffer at This Morning said she was always willing to cause controversy from the word go. Such programmes involve a chat with a producer in advance, and Katie would immediately come up with a firm line on something, and then wheeled on-air to spout it with little thought from either her or producers about where it would end. So in 2013 when she told Philip and Holly she wouldn't let her children play with someone called Tyler or Chardonnay or named after geography, it was pointed out one of her children was called India and the clip went viral.  Katie learned to make money by being rude and unapologetic, and the media learned to shore up their audience figures with a wingnut. Inevitably, she was offered a national newspaper column, a place in the Big Brother house, and more opprobrium as the hate multiplied. In 2015 she used her column to denounce migrants as cockroaches, and it quietly disappeared before she popped up at another website which racked up &pound150,000 damages plus costs for her groundless claim that a pair of Muslim brothers banned from travelling to Disneyland were linked to al Qaeda. She met holocaust deniers, tweeted about being with crew of a Save the Children ship she didn't board, and had repeated applications to join UKIP rejected. She made a habit out of getting it wrong. She moved on to LBC, left after calling for a final solution to Islamic terror, was questioned but not charged over alleged hate crimes, and more recently staged a picture with children at a school without their parents' or teachers' permission, a gross breach of journalistic ethics. She has her own website and, one hopes, has invested in some defamation legal insurance. Now she's been sued over a defamatory tweet, lost her home, and had to enter an agreement with her creditors. All of it is due to the simple fact that she attempted to be a journalist without any of the necessary skills.  If Katie had experience of working in the media before she became its favourite monster, she'd have known that what you don't say is just as important as what you do. By all means say you're snobby about the name Charmaine, but it might be an idea to know Shakespeare was happy to use it for one of his characters. If you make a habit of racking up legal bills for your employer, be careful with what you publish on social media. If you are caught lying, stop doing it. Steer clear of people with swastikas in their Twitter handles and  you don't know what defamation is, look it up. But more than anything else the lesson that Katie needed to learn was this: that becoming a hate figure is a viable but short media career. She chose a path that was an ever-decreasing spiral of bile, and it was only ever going to lead her into peril. I'm not sure she knows how she got there. She started out as entertainment, and ended up with the twin Pyrrhic victories of being praised by Donald Trump and winning an IPSO ruling against the Daily Mirror about the fact she was not detained for taking ketamine in South Africa, but for spreading racial hatred. Now she's broke and the only people still paying attention are creditors and knicker-snfing Nazis.  Katie was not a journalist but a controversialist - built and brought down by her ignorance of how journalism works. Her name is flung at others who make a much better fist of it, along with accusations they all want to be like her. Nothing could be further from the truth - journalists, above all things, want to be right. Katie was just a story, and it's a sad indictment of the media that it relied for attention on a sick woman spouting proto-fascist lies. But the principal blame is on Katie herself. She had enough clues, from as early as her first interview after leaving The Apprentice when Nick Hewer said her new brand had made you famous, but it's made you loathed. And where's it going to take you now? She never seems to have asked where it would lead. Even with training, she would never have made much of a journo. She has a thick skin and bloody-mindedness, but seems to lack empathy, accuracy, self-doubt or persuasiveness. She is a curiosity, but doesn't have any. The first rule of journalism is 'never become the story'. Not just because it's professionally embarrassing, but because all copy finishes the same way - with the word 'ends'. * Fleet Street Fox's new book, A Bluffer's Guide To Journalism, is published in March. story: NewsGirl, 12, is raped by man who took her to nightclub to down Jagerbombs and forced her to kiss his girlfriendJohn Phoenix, 30, of Leigh, had been messaging the victim online for a couple of weeks before he took her back to his home and attacked herShare&nbspByJohnathan Pickles07:53, 18 SEP 2018Updated07:59, 18 SEP 2018NewsPhoenix was sentenced to 14 years in prison for the rape and five years in prison for child abduction"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who lured a 12-year-old girl from her home, plied her with alcohol and raped her during a 48-hour period has been described as every parent's worst nightmare. John Phoenix, 30, of Leigh, was sentenced at Bolton Crown Court last week, after pleading guilty to rape and being found guilty of child abduction at an earlier hearing. In September 2017, a 12-year-old girl was reported missing from her home in Leigh. Police traced the girl to Phoenix’s address two days later and established that he had been messaging the victim on social media for a number of weeks. The night she went missing Phoenix took the girl to a nightclub in Leigh where he plied her with alcohol and kissed her before he took her back to his home. She woke up 14 hours later. Police rescued the victim from Phoenix's flat in Leigh, Greater Manchester following a search after her mother reported her missing on the night she was picked up by the cab. Phoenix was sentenced to 14 years in prison for the rape, and five years in prison for child abduction but the sentences will run concurrently. His girlfriend Stacey Westwood, 29, admitted sexual assault and was given four months jail suspended for two years. She was also ordered to sign the Sex Offender Register for seven years.  In a statement, the girl's mother said: ''This is every parent’s worst nightmare and I feel like I have failed in my parental duties. I felt so angry when he said that he thought she was 17. I am so worried about her, I have even contemplated sleeping by the front door just in case she tries to leave again. “She is so precious to me and I don’t want to hear how she blames herself for what happened and how she wants to die. When I found out what the female did to my daughter as well, I felt sick. I found it hard to comprehend.” Phoenix's victim has reportedly tried to hang herself following her ordeal. The girl said: “What happened with John Phoenix will change me forever I thought he was a friend. Finding out the science results, I couldn’t believe it and I was so upset. I will not refer to it as sex, I will refer to it as the mean thing because it was a mean thing to do. “I was so upset with myself because I didn’t think an adult of John’s age would ever do anything like that to a 12 year old. “If I don’t really know what John wanted then how will I be able to judge anybody else in the future. I feel like I will be in the dark.”  Prosecuting, Barbara Webster, said: “He ordered a taxi from her house which then took her to his house. She arrived at his house that evening and Stacey Westwood answered the door. He got changed and they went to [a club]. “Alcoholic drinks were then bought by him and Stacey Westwood and given to the victim. They left the club around 3am and at this point the victim was very drunk. They went home and went to sleep. She woke at around 5pm and said that her vagina felt sore. “He showed her a picture of her on social media that said she was a missing 12 year old. He said ‘is that you?’ and she said ‘yes.’ “She stayed with him and they went to [the club] again but then went home and did some jagerbombs. “On Saturday September 23, he went out with a friend and she stayed at his apartment and watched TV. He came home at around 4am and then later that morning the police came around and found her at his house. In mitigation defence lawyer Paul Treble, said: “The defence’s case is that he thought that she was over 16. She told a lady that she was over 16 and the defendant thought that she was over 16.

Sophie Hinchclfe , known as Mrs Hinch , has become an online sensation after filming herself cleaning her immaculate Essex home, which she shares with husband Jamie and pet pooch Henry.  Her spotless kitchen and lounge have become the envy of many and her amusing commentary as she cleans is now inspiring others to don their rubber gloves and whack out their feather dusters. People are so in awe of her vivacious personality and catchphrases - including 'All the best' - she has won a legion of fans. With 468,000 follower and counting, they call themselves Hinch Army.   Sophie even appeared on This Morning today, alongside presenters Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield, sparking even more of a cleaning frenzy.  The 28-year-old, who got married last month, admits she cleans for at least 30 minutes a day. Her pride and joy is her shiny, streak-free kitchen sink. She stores a lot of her products in a wardrobe in her garage which she calls her 'Narnia'. And she swears by certain items which she buys from shops such as Wilko, B&ampM and Poundstretcher. Some of these stores have now even dedicated shelf space with the sign 'Hinch Army' for shoppers, The hairdresser has also given all her favourite cleaning items unusual nicknames.  The one item fans will be most familiar with is 'Minkeh' which has become like gold dust and is sold out everywhere, thanks to Sophie. She uses Minkeh , Dave , Buddy , Pinkeh  and Vera . Her other top products are Flash with Febreze Bathroom Spray, CIF Stainless Steel Spray, Toilet Duck 4in1 Liquid Cleaner in the scent Fresh Pine, 1001 Carpet Spray and Zoflora. Most of the products cost &pound1 but because of Sophie's recommendations, many are selling out, or going on sale online at massively inflated prices due to the high demand.  Sophie created her profile @MrsHinchHome_X_ in March.  However, it has only been since July that the number of followers has sky rocketed since she started sharing her cleaning routines.  It just spiralled and I couldn't be more grateful, she said. It started off as around 200 or 500 [followers] a month and now it's as many as 35,000 a day. It's in the last four to six weeks that it has gone viral. I've got followers from Ireland, the US and Australia and they are all amazing. Sophie also admits cleaning has helped her cope with her anxiety. I'm a worrier, she added. For me, to keep my mind off of what was worrying me would be to clean and organise something and love the end result.  It took my mind off worrying. It helps me control my panic attacks too. Since I've started the account others have messaged me saying I've changed their lives and helped them with their mental health which to me is simply amazing. I get thousands of messages each day like this. Here are a selection of tips from her ever-growing Instagram page. 1. What to do with plugs Pour some soda crystals down each plug then use white vinegar spray then use neat disinfectant  while boiling the kettle. Wash it all away with boiling water. 2.How to get sinks sparkling Use disinfectant spray, add a little bit of water, then wipe down excess before using stainless steel cleaner  before using a cloth to finish it off.  3.Removing food mess from wooden floors Spray degreaser over the affected area and use an electric toothbrush to remove it before using a cloth. 4.Keeping your hob stain free Use a cloth and cleaning paste, such as The Pink Stuff. After a few minutes rinse with another wet cloth and repeat.  5.Cleaning your washing machine Slide out the drawer and use a bathroom spray, before spraying limescale remover into the gap where the drawer was. Pull back the rim and use bathroom spray before wiping down and using an electric toothbrush to remove any dirt. 6.Making sure mirrors are streak free Use white vinegar spray, and use a fluffy microfibre cloth to wipe until all smears are gone. 7.Getting rid of mattress stains Sprinkle bicarb on the affected area and rub in with latex gloves. Then you can vacuum it off after an hour.
